title: Acute Compartment Syndrome
diagnosis_topic: Compartment syndrome of the leg following tibia fracture
setup_script: A 23-year-old man sustained a closed mid-shaft tibia fracture while snowboarding. His leg was splinted in the field. He now reports escalating pain despite analgesia and numbness in his foot.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 135/85 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8 C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses the injured leg
dynamic_flow.reply: Tight swollen compartments, pain out of proportion to exam, pain with passive dorsiflexion of the foot, diminished sensation between first and second toes.
Anterior compartment pressure 45 mmHg with diastolic BP 85 mmHg (delta pressure 40 mmHg).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident removes circumferential dressings and loosens splint
dynamic_flow.reply: Pain briefly improves but remains severe.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults orthopedic surgery emergently
dynamic_flow.reply: Taken to OR for four-compartment fasciotomy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis or dismisses complaints
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops permanent motor deficits and contractures.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders analgesics alone without evaluation

dynamic_flow.reply: Compartment pressure within 30 mmHg of diastolic BP or classic clinical signs mandate fasciotomy.
Wounds left open with negative pressure dressings; plan for delayed closure or grafting.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates patient about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: High-energy fractures, reperfusion injury, tight casts increase risk.
Check creatine kinase and renal function; ensure adequate hydration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions prophylactic fasciotomy in vascular injuries
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider in prolonged ischemia after revascularization.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of compartment syndrome based on clinical signs
Measurement and interpretation of compartment pressures
Timely consultation and performance of fasciotomy
Avoidance of delays that lead to irreversible muscle and nerve damage
